bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 3, 1890

div1.p: Lazear describes sightseeing in London. He is preparing to depart for Paris.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 3, 1890

opener.dateline:
2 Queens Square Place
London. W.C.
Sunday August 3, 1890

div1.p:
I feel very well satisfied
with my day's work to-day, as I spent the
whole day at the two best things about
London. One is St. Paul's Cathedral and the
other is the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew.

In the morning I went to service at the
Cathedral. They had the full morning
service including those parts which are
usually omitted in our country. The
chants were mostly sung to precisely the
same tunes as they used at the cathedral
in Edinburgh. I enjoyed sitting in that
magnificent building and looking around.

After lunch I took one of the Thames
steamers and rode up the Thames to Kew.
The Thames above London is a very beau-
tiful stream. The Gardens are very fine,
there are hot-houses with every imaginable
plant. The Palm House is sixty-six feet
high and there are palms reaching to
the roof. There grounds have groves of
all kinds of trees with beautiful vistas.
They allow the people to walk on the grass
which adds to the pleasure. There are
250 acres in the Gardens.

We are just about to start for Paris.
On Monday I went down to Green-
wich then returned and did Westminster
Abbey for the second time, then
I walked along Pall Mall and
identified all the club-houses.
In the evening I went to the
Crystal Palace about which I
will tell you again as I am
very much hurried now.

Yesterday I did nothing but make
arrangements and make purchases.
I got the neuralgia crystals but they
do not come as you said.
They have large crystals and small
crystals so I got three large crystals.
I can really say that I am
not sorry to leave London. This whole
island is very wearying in the long
run. The people may not be all
drunkards and thieves but a large
portion certainly are.
